questions.question: Question 1: From which period of embryogenesis does the liver become the chief site of hematopoiesis?
questions.explanation:
613 
Sold by @itachibot From the 3rd month of embryogenesis, the liver becomes the chief site of hematopoiesis. Development of hematopoietic tissues: • Yolk sac - blood cell progenitors first appear during the 3rd week • Liver - hematopoietic stem cells migrate to the liver during the 3rd month of embryogenesis • Bone marrow - hematopoiesis starts in bone marrow during the 4th month of intrauterine life 
and becomes the predominant site after birth

questions.question: Question 2: Which cells in the bone marrow are referred to as nurse cells?
questions.explanation:
Nurse cells are specialized macrophages in the bone marrow that assist in the development of red 
blood cells (RBCs).

questions.question:
Question 3: Bone marrow biopsy of a normal adult is given below. What is the ratio of structures marked 
A and B? 608 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The structures marked A are fat cells and B are hematopoietic elements. The normal ratio of fat 
cells to hematopoietic elements in a normal adult is 1:1. In hypoplastic states (like aplastic anemia), the proportion of fat cells is greatly increased 
(increased fat to cell ratio). Conversely, fat cells often disappear in conditions like hematopoietic tumors and in diseases with 
compensatory hyperplasias (like hemolytic anemias) and neoplastic proliferations such as 
leukemias (decreased fat-to-cell ratio).

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is a marker for pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells?
questions.explanation:
614 
Sold by @itachibot CD34 is an antigen of pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells of many lineages.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is called leukocyte common antigen?
questions.explanation: CD45 is called leukocyte common antigen because it is found in all leukocytes.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Kostmann syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Kostmann syndrome is characterized by neutropenia. It is a rare congenital condition in which inherited defects in specific genes impair granulocytic 
differentiation. This results in severe congenital neutropenia. It presents in young children as recurrent bacterial infections (such as otitis media, cellulitis) and 
oral ulcers. It is associated with an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

questions.question:
Question 7: What is the most common cause of agranulocytosis? 609 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of agranulocytosis is drug toxicity. Causes of agranulocytosis include: • Inadequate or ineffective granulopoiesis - • Suppression of hematopoietic stem cells - aplastic anemia, infiltrative marrow disorders • Suppression of committed granulocytic precursors • Ineffective hematopoiesis - megaloblastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndromes • Congenital conditions - Kostmann syndrome 615 
Sold by @itachibot • Increased destruction or sequestration of neutrophils - • Immunological injury to neutrophils - idiopathic, systemic lupus erythematosus, drug exposure • Increased peripheral utilization - bacterial, fungal, or rickettsial infections • Splenomegaly

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient who was started on chemotherapy 2 weeks ago is found to have a neutrophil count 
of 2000/mm3. Below what neutrophil count is he at risk of developing serious infections?
questions.explanation: Serious infections are most likely when the neutrophil count falls below 500/mm3.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 5-year-old boy is brought with complaints of episodes of severe, violent coughs, followed by 
a high-pitch intake of breath that sounds like a whoop. These coughing episodes are usually 
followed by vomiting. He and his family are refugees and his prior vaccination records are not 
available. Lab investigations of this child will likely reveal which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of whooping cough or pertussis. It is due to Bordetella 
pertussis infection and results in lymphocytosis. Causes of lymphocytosis include: • Pertussis • Tuberculosis • Brucellosis • Hepatitis A • Cytomegalovirus • Epstein-Barr virus

questions.question:
Question 10: A 50-year-old man admitted to ICU develops sepsis 3 days after insertion of a central venous 
catheter. A peripheral blood smear reveals the following. What does the structure marked by 
the arrow indicate? 610 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given peripheral smear, prepared from an individual with bacterial sepsis, shows reactive 
changes in neutrophils. The arrow-marked structure is a Döhle body. 616 
Sold by @itachibot Reactive changes in neutrophils associated with leukocytosis in severe inflammatory disorders 
are: • Toxic granules, which are coarser and darker than the normal neutrophilic granules, represent 
abnormal azurophilic (primary) granules • Döhle bodies are patches of the dilated endoplasmic reticulum that appear as sky-blue 
cytoplasmic puddles • Toxic cytoplasmic vacuoles The image given below shows a neutrophil with cytoplasmic vacuoles. 617 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following does not cause follicular hyperplasia of the lymph nodes?
questions.explanation:
B-cell lymphoma results in malignant proliferation within the lymph node, not follicular 
hyperplasia. Follicular hyperplasia is a benign condition caused by stimuli that activate humoral immune 
responses. It may occur in: • Rheumatoid arthritis • Toxoplasmosis • Early stages of HIV infection It is defined by the presence of large oblong germinal centres (secondary follicles), which are 
surrounded by a collar of small, resting naive B cells (mantle zone). 618 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is not a feature of reactive lymphoid hyperplasia?

options.c: No variation in shape and size of the follicles

questions.explanation:
In reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, there is marked variation in the shape and size of follicles. Features favoring reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, which are absent in neoplastic follicles are: • Preservation of the lymph node architecture, including the interfollicular T-cell zones and the 
sinusoids • Marked variation in the shape and size of the follicles • Presence of frequent mitotic figures and phagocytic macrophages • Recognizable light and dark zones

questions.question: Question 13: In which of the following organs are tingible body macrophages found?
questions.explanation:
Tingible-body macrophages are found in lymph nodes. A tingible-body macrophage is a type of macrophage predominantly found in germinal 
centers containing many phagocytosed apoptotic cell debris. This debris is referred to as tingible 
bodies (tingible meaning stainable). The presence of these macrophages suggests non-neoplastic 
reactive hyperplasia of the lymph node, or can be seen as the stars in the starry sky appearance of 
Burkitt lymphoma. 619 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 16-year-old boy presented with complaints of fever, sore throat, and enlarged lymph nodes. 
Paul Bunnell's test was done and found to be positive. What type of lymphoid hyperplasia is 
seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis. Acute viral infections, like 
infectious mononucleosis, produce paracortical hyperplasia. There are three types of lymph node hyperplasia. They are: • Follicular hyperplasia • Paracortical hyperplasia • Sinus histiocytosis (reticular hyperplasia) Paracortical hyperplasia is seen in the T-cell-containing paracortical region of the lymph node. It 
is caused by stimuli that trigger T-cell–mediated immune responses. The involved regions 
typically contain: 620 
Sold by @itachibot • Immunoblasts • Activated T-cells 3-4 times the size of resting lymphocytes t • Round nuclei • Open chromatin • Several prominent nucleoli • Moderate amounts of pale cytoplasm • Hypertrophy of sinusoidal and vascular endothelial cells, with infiltrating macrophages and 
eosinophils

questions.question:
Question 15: In patients with breast cancer with lymph node metastases, which of the following changes is 
seen in affected lymph nodes?
questions.explanation:
In the case of lymph node metastases, there is prominent reticular hyperplasia. Reticular hyperplasia or sinus histiocytosis refers to an increase in the number and size of the 
cells that line lymphatic sinusoids. Although nonspecific, this form of hyperplasia may be 
particularly prominent in lymph nodes draining cancers such as carcinoma of the breast. The lining lymphatic endothelial cells are markedly hypertrophied and macrophages are greatly 
increased in numbers, resulting in the expansion and distension of the sinuses. The image given below shows reticular hyperplasia in the lymph node.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following statements about hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis is false?

options.a: There is systemic activation of macrophages and CD8+ T cells
options.b: The most common trigger is infection with Epstein-Barr virus
options.c: It presents as an acute febrile illness with hepatosplenomegaly
options.d: Hemophagocytosis seen in bone marrow is sufficient for diagnosis

questions.explanation:
Hemophagocytosis is usually seen on bone marrow examination, but it is neither sufficient nor 
required to make the diagnosis of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). 621 
Sold by @itachibot HLH is a reactive condition also known as macrophage-activation syndrome. The common feature 
of all forms of HLH is the systemic activation of macrophages and CD8+ T-cells. The most common trigger for HLH is an infection, particularly with EBV (Epstein-Barr virus). It is 
characterized by acute febrile illness associated with splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and cytopenias.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is not a feature in patients with hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis?
questions.explanation:
Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) is associated with very high serum ferritin levels. Laboratory findings in HLH include: • Anemia • Thrombocytopenia • High serum ferritin • High plasma IL2 receptor levels • Elevated liver enzyme levels • High triglyceride levels • Features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) 622 
Sold by @itachibot Hypertensive Vascular Disease and Atherosclerosis
